document_title: A multi-omics longitudinal study of the murine retinal response to chronic low-dose irradiation and simulated microgravity
summary_full: This study investigated the long-term effects of spaceflight hazards, specifically radiation and simulated microgravity (hindlimb unloading), on the murine retina using a multi-omics approach. Researchers analyzed epigenomic (DNA methylation) and transcriptomic (gene expression) data from mice exposed to these conditions for 21 days, with retinal analysis at 7 days, 1 month, and 4 months post-exposure. They identified thousands of differentially methylated loci/regions and differentially expressed genes, noting that methylation changes correlated most strongly across different conditions at the same time point. Key biological processes affected included nucleotide metabolism, which showed activation at 1 month and suppression at 7 days and 4 months post-exposure. Notch and Wnt signaling pathways were altered 4 months post-exposure. A total of 23 genes exhibited significant changes in both methylation and expression, including those involved in retinal function and inflammation. The study highlights the complex, time-dependent molecular responses of the retina to these spaceflight stressors.
key_findings: Identified 4178 differentially methylated loci/regions and 457 differentially expressed genes in the murine retina following exposure to simulated microgravity and/or low-dose irradiation.
Nucleotide metabolism was consistently affected, showing activation at 1 month and suppression at 7 days and 4 months post-exposure across all conditions.
Notch and Wnt signaling pathways showed alterations 4 months after exposure.
23 genes demonstrated significant changes in both DNA methylation and gene expression, including genes related to retinal function and inflammatory responses.
Methylation differences showed the highest correlation across different exposure conditions when analyzed at the same post-exposure time point.
future_research_fields: Investigating the specific molecular mechanisms underlying the observed changes in nucleotide metabolism and Wnt/Notch signaling.
Exploring the long-term consequences of these retinal changes on visual function and potential disease development.
Validating these findings in more realistic space radiation models (e.g., GCR simulations) and with larger sample sizes.
Utilizing single-cell multi-omics approaches to resolve cell-type-specific responses within the heterogeneous retinal tissue.
Developing and testing countermeasures to mitigate the observed retinal damage and functional alterations.

conclusions: This multi-omics longitudinal study reveals significant and time-dependent changes in the epigenomic and transcriptomic landscape of the murine retina in response to simulated microgravity and low-dose irradiation. The findings highlight the complex interplay of these spaceflight stressors and their impact on critical biological pathways, suggesting potential long-term risks to retinal health. The identified molecular alterations provide a foundation for understanding the mechanisms of retinal dysfunction in space and for developing targeted mitigation strategies.
impact_statement: This research provides crucial insights into the molecular mechanisms of retinal damage caused by spaceflight hazards, informing strategies to protect astronaut vision during long-duration missions.
